pros:
I've been volunteering at GVFB for a while. 
Nice place to learn new skills and help the community.
The staff is very friendly.
Lovely caring humans who want to be apart of helping our community.
cons: Management is terrible. Too many, top heavy. Management will try to compare you to your colleagues and drive competition. Toxic work environment, Managers email you on weekends and expect a response. No work life balance.

pros: really great pay and compensation from a nonprofit
cons: can be toxic environment if your views don't align with that of leadership.

pros: Great people and culture to work with
cons: There are no cons to think of

review_title: Food Bank helping those in need is worthy career
pros: Good to know you are helping disadvantaged people. Most of the staff pull their weight so you aren't having to cover for others. Most people are dedicated to the job. A few folks try to advance themselves by tattling on others. The society has a good working relationship with its volunteers.
cons: Painful to deal with con artists when you knOw others need the food bank. Not much room for advancement ... A fairly flat organization. Sometimes you are working a crazy amount of hours ... especially just before Christmas.

review_title: Passionate Workers discouraged by Terrible Management
pros:
1) Decent pay for low qualifications
2) Anyone who isn't in a management position are some of the greatest people I've worked with
3) Working with volunteers is an enriching experience, simply because the volunteers are wonderful people.
cons:
1) Management is discouraging and will constantly talk behind your back
2) Job description at the time of hiring was not correct to actual work done 80% of the time (mostly stocking shelves)
3) From my perspective they fire people without any reason aside from not aligning with management's views (not really going to get into it here)
4) Rather than working with you on any issues that you may be experiencing with the position, management goes two options: a) They fire you b) They tell you you're wrong and refuse to admit any wrongdoing on their end
6) Hubs Assistant position, which is now Distribution Coordinator, has very low bar for growth.
7) Scheduling is late almost all the time for something that seems simple. 
8) CEO needs to learn to take criticisms as an opportunity for growth rather than getting defensive. (Btw, no longer Aart Hess, currently David Long)
9) This place is full of both management and front-line workers badmouthing each other, that's managers badmouthing other managers as well, the work environment here has become toxic that can be felt by all.
